docs.title: Popsims
docs.text: Ultracool dwarf population simulation routines

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
pip install popsims

Notebook example: https://github.com/caganze/popsims/blob/main/examples/ExampleNotebook.ipynb

Documentation (in progress):

docs.title: galaxy.py module
docs.text: The module galaxy.py provides functions for simulating populations of stars in the Milky Way. It includes classes for representing different galactic components (e.g. thin disk, thick disk, halo), as well as functions for transforming coordinates and computing densities.

docs.title: Exponential density profile
docs.text: The exponential_density function returns the density profile of a galaxy with the following equation: $$ density = zpart * rpart$$ where: $zpart = e^{\frac{-abs(z-Zsun)}{H}}$ $rpart = e^{\frac{-(r-Rsun)}{L}}$

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• r (list or array): galactocentric radius
  • z (list or array): galactocentric height
  • H (list or array): scaleheight
  • L (list or array): scalelength

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: • density (float or array): density at the given radius and height

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: x = exponential_density(8700, 100, 300, 2600)

docs.title: Spheroid density profile
docs.text: The spheroid_density function returns the density profile of a spheroidal galaxy with the following equation: $$ density = \frac{Rsun}{((r^2+\frac{z^2}{q^2})^\frac{1}{2})^n} $$ where: $Rsun$ is the galactocentric radius of the sun $q$ is the flattening parameter $n$ is the power-law exponent

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• r (list or array): galactocentric radius
  • z (list or array): galactocentric height
  • q (float): flattening parameter
  • n (float): power-law exponent

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: • density (float or array): density at the given radius and height

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: x = spheroid_density(8700, 100, 0.64, n=2.77)

docs.title: GalacticComponent
docs.text: A meta class for galactic components.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
• H: The height of the disk component.
  • L: The length of the disk component.
  • q: The q parameter of the halo component.
  • n: The n parameter of the halo component.

docs.title: Transform to cylindrical coordinates
docs.text: The transform_to_cylindrical function converts the given spherical coordinates to cylindrical coordinates. It returns the galactocentric radius and height in cylindrical coordinates.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• l (list or array): galactic longitude (in radians)
  • b (list or array): galactic latitude (in radians)
  • ds (list or array): heliocentric distance

docs.title: M31Halo
docs.text: The M31Halo class is a subclass of GalacticComponent that represents the power-law stellar density of the halo of the Andromeda galaxy (M31), as measured by Ibata et al. 2014.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• q (float, optional): The flattening parameter of the halo. Defaults to 1.11.
  • gamma (float, optional): The power-law exponent of the halo. Defaults to -3.

docs.title: stellar_density(self, r, z)
docs.text: Computes the stellar density at a particular position in the halo.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• r (float or array-like): The galactocentric radius of the position(s) to compute the density for, in units of length.
  • z (float or array-like): The galactocentric height of the position(s) to compute the density for, in units of length.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: • The unitless stellar density at the specified position(s). If r and z are arrays, the returned value will also be an array with the same shape.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
m31halo = M31Halo()
density = m31halo.stellar_density(100, -100)

docs.title: Disk
docs.text: A subclass of GalacticComponent representing the disk component of a galaxy.

docs.title: stellar_density(r, z)
docs.text: Compute the stellar density at a particular position.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• r: galacto-centric radius (astropy.quantity)
  • z: galacto-centric height (astropy.quantity)

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: A unit-less stellar density.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: d = Disk.stellar_density(100*u.pc, -100*u.pc)

docs.title: Tutorials
docs.text:
#imports 
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
%matplotlib inline

import popsims
from popsims.simulator import Population, pop_mags
from popsims.galaxy import Disk, Halo
from popsims.plot_style import  plot_style

plot_style()

import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

#draw masses from a power-law IMF and uniform ages
#obtain temperatures from Baraffe et al.2003 relations
p=Population(evolmodel= 'baraffe2003',
              imf_power= -0.6,
              binary_fraction=0.2,
              age_range=[0.01, 14],
              mass_range=[0.01, 1],
             nsample=1e5)

p.simulate()

#define a galaxy density model and draw distances in a given direction
disk= Disk(H=300, L=2600)
tdisk=Disk(H=900, L=3600)
halo= Halo()
model= disk+0.12*tdisk+(1/400)*halo
p.add_distances(model, 0, np.pi/3,0.1, 1000, dsteps=5000)

#add magnitudes from pre-defined filters or pre-define polynomial cofficients
p.add_magnitudes(['LSST_G', 'LSST_R', 'LSST_I', 'LSST_Y',  'LSST_Z'], get_from='spt')

p.visualize(keys=['spt', 'temperature', 'LSST_G', 'distance'])

#visualize countours in galaxy model
ax=model.plot_countours(log=True, rmax=50_000, zmax=10000, zmin=-10000, npoints=2000)
